title: Amos Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 2.

questions.question: For what reason did the LORD declare punishment upon Moab?
options: Because he burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime
Because he destroyed the palaces of Jerusalem
Because he sold the righteous for silver
Because he ignored the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Because he burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime
questions.explanation: Amos 2:1 states that Moab is punished because he burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime.

questions.question: What will happen to the palaces of Kerioth according to Amos 2:2?
options: They shall be devoured by fire
They will be rebuilt
They will be given to Judah
They will remain untouched
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be devoured by fire
questions.explanation: Amos 2:2 says that the LORD will send fire upon Moab and it shall devour the palaces of Kerioth.

questions.question: Who will be cut off from Moab as punishment?
options: The judge and princes
The priests and elders
The king and the soldiers
The prophets and teachers
questions.correctAnswer: The judge and princes
questions.explanation: Amos 2:3 states that the LORD will cut off the judge and slay all the princes of Moab.

questions.question: Why is Judah punished according to Amos 2:4?
options: Because they despised the law of the LORD and did not keep His commandments
Because they burned the bones of the king
Because they worshiped other gods openly
Because they attacked Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because they despised the law of the LORD and did not keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Amos 2:4 states Judah is punished for despising the law of the LORD and not keeping His commandments.

questions.question: What will happen to the palaces of Jerusalem?
options: They will be devoured by fire
They will be rebuilt
They will be given to Moab
They will be protected
questions.correctAnswer: They will be devoured by fire
questions.explanation: Amos 2:5 says the LORD will send a fire upon Judah that shall devour the palaces of Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Amos 2:6, what did Israel do that caused punishment?
options: Sold the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
Built idols in the temple
Refused to listen to the prophets
Attacked their neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Sold the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
questions.explanation: Amos 2:6 states Israel sold the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes.

questions.question: What sinful act involving young women is mentioned in Amos 2:7?
options: A man and his father going in unto the same maid
Young women worshiping idols
Young women being sold for silver
Young women leading false prophets
questions.correctAnswer: A man and his father going in unto the same maid
questions.explanation: Amos 2:7 describes the sin of a man and his father going in unto the same maid, profaning God's holy name.

questions.question: What do Israel’s people do with clothes laid to pledge by every altar according to Amos 2:8?
options: They lay themselves down upon them and drink the wine of the condemned
They burn them as offerings
They use them to clothe the poor
They sell them for silver
questions.correctAnswer: They lay themselves down upon them and drink the wine of the condemned
questions.explanation: Amos 2:8 says they lay themselves down on clothes laid to pledge by every altar and drink the wine of the condemned.

questions.question: Who did the LORD destroy before Israel, as described in Amos 2:9?
options: The Amorite
The Moabite
The Edomite
The Philistine
questions.correctAnswer: The Amorite
questions.explanation: Amos 2:9 states that the LORD destroyed the Amorite before Israel.

questions.question: How long did the LORD lead Israel through the wilderness according to Amos 2:10?
options: Forty years
Twenty years
Ten years
Seventy years
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Amos 2:10 says the LORD led Israel forty years through the wilderness.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD raised up prophets and Nazarites from Israel's sons and young men.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 2:11 confirms that the LORD raised up sons for prophets and young men for Nazarites.

questions.question: True or False: Israel gave Nazarites wine to drink and commanded the prophets to prophesy more.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 2:12 says Israel gave Nazarites wine to drink and commanded prophets to prophesy not.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 2:16, the courageous among the mighty will stand firm on that day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 2:16 says the courageous among the mighty shall flee away naked in that day.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Therefore the flight shall perish from the _______' (Amos 2:14).
options: swift
strong
mighty
wicked
questions.correctAnswer: swift
questions.explanation: Amos 2:14 states, 'Therefore the flight shall perish from the swift.'

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I brought you up from the land of _______, and led you forty years through the wilderness' (Amos 2:10).
options: Egypt
Babylon
Assyria
Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Amos 2:10 says the LORD brought Israel up from Egypt and led them forty years through the wilderness.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with integrity at work, noticing injustice around them. Based on Amos 2:6-7, what biblical truth would you share about honesty and fairness?
options: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes is condemned by God
It's acceptable to exploit others if it benefits your family
Dishonesty is only a minor issue in God’s eyes
God overlooks injustice when it benefits the community
questions.correctAnswer: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes is condemned by God
questions.explanation: Amos 2:6-7 condemns selling the righteous and exploiting the poor, teaching us to maintain honesty and fairness in our work and dealings with others. This reflects God’s call for integrity (Amos 2:6-7, 2:8, 2:4).

questions.question: How does Amos 2:4-5 teach us about obedience to God’s commandments in family and church life?
options: Despising God’s law leads to punishment and loss of blessing
Ignoring God’s commandments has no real consequences
Only outward worship matters, not obedience
God only punishes nations, not families
questions.correctAnswer: Despising God’s law leads to punishment and loss of blessing
questions.explanation: Amos 2:4-5 shows that Judah’s punishment came because they despised God’s law and did not keep His commandments, reminding believers that obedience is essential in family and church life (Amos 2:4-5, 2:12).

questions.question: A believer is feeling pressured by trials and enemies. Based on Amos 2:13-16, what encouragement can you give about God’s sovereignty and protection?
options: No one can deliver themselves on the day of the LORD, but God’s judgment is sure
Human strength guarantees deliverance
Fleeing is always the best option
God abandons those who face trouble
questions.correctAnswer: No one can deliver themselves on the day of the LORD, but God’s judgment is sure
questions.explanation: Amos 2:13-16 emphasizes God’s sovereign judgment where human strength fails, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice and protection even in trials (Amos 2:13-16).

questions.question: Based on Amos 2:10-11, what does God’s raising up of prophets and Nazarites teach us about spiritual discipline and leadership?
options: God calls and equips people for spiritual leadership and holiness
Leadership is only about power and influence
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary for believers
Prophets are no longer relevant
questions.correctAnswer: God calls and equips people for spiritual leadership and holiness
questions.explanation: Amos 2:10-11 shows God’s role in raising prophets and Nazarites, highlighting the importance of spiritual discipline and leadership in the community of faith (Amos 2:10-11).

questions.question: How does Amos 2:12 warn us about the danger of opposing God’s messengers in church life and personal devotion?
options: Rejecting God’s prophets leads to spiritual decline
It’s acceptable to silence those who challenge us
Prophets should only teach what pleases the crowd
God’s word can be ignored without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God’s prophets leads to spiritual decline
questions.explanation: Amos 2:12 criticizes giving wine to Nazarites and commanding prophets not to prophesy, warning believers that opposing God’s messengers harms spiritual growth and obedience (Amos 2:12, 2:4).

questions.question: A believer asks about God’s justice concerning family purity and holiness. Based on Amos 2:7, what teaching would you share?
options: Profaning God’s holy name through immoral acts is condemned
Family purity is not important in the sight of God
God overlooks immoral behavior
Only public sin matters, not private sin
questions.correctAnswer: Profaning God’s holy name through immoral acts is condemned
questions.explanation: Amos 2:7 condemns immoral acts that profane God’s holy name, teaching believers to uphold purity and holiness within family and personal life (Amos 2:7).

questions.question: How does Amos 2:1-3 demonstrate the importance of trusting God’s justice rather than seeking revenge?
options: God promises to punish transgressions; we should trust Him rather than take vengeance
We should take revenge quickly to restore justice
God ignores offenses against others
Personal revenge is encouraged in the Bible
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to punish transgressions; we should trust Him rather than take vengeance
questions.explanation: Amos 2:1-3 reveals God’s judgment on Moab for burning the king’s bones, teaching believers to trust God’s justice instead of seeking personal revenge (Amos 2:1-3).

questions.question: True or False: Amos 2:5 teaches that God will send a fire to devour the palaces of Jerusalem as a consequence of disobedience.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 2:5 clearly states that God will send fire upon Judah to devour the palaces of Jerusalem because of their rebellion and disobedience (Amos 2:5).

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 2:9-10, God’s past acts of deliverance from Egypt and defeat of the Amorites assure us of His ongoing faithfulness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 2:9-10 recounts God’s powerful acts of deliverance, reminding believers of His faithfulness and encouraging trust in His continued care (Amos 2:9-10).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Amos 2:8 says they lay themselves down upon clothes laid to ______ by every altar, and drink the wine of the condemned in the house of their god.
options: pledge
burn
hide
sell
questions.correctAnswer: pledge
questions.explanation: Amos 2:8 uses the imagery of laying down on clothes given as pledge and drinking the wine of the condemned, illustrating exploitation and injustice (Amos 2:8).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with humility and contentment. How does Amos 2:13-16 illustrate the futility of relying on human strength instead of God?
options: No human strength or skill can deliver on the day of the LORD
Human courage always guarantees success
Physical strength is more important than spiritual trust
We should rely on weapons and speed to save ourselves
questions.correctAnswer: No human strength or skill can deliver on the day of the LORD
questions.explanation: Amos 2:13-16 describes how the swift, mighty, and skilled will not deliver themselves, teaching believers to humble themselves and trust in God’s power rather than their own (Amos 2:13-16).

questions.question: How does Amos 2:4 teach about the importance of following God’s law in the upbringing of children and spiritual discipline?
options: Walking in the ways of their fathers who obeyed God is crucial for spiritual health
Parental example has no effect on children’s faith
Children should make their own rules separate from God’s law
Ignoring God’s commandments is acceptable in family life
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in the ways of their fathers who obeyed God is crucial for spiritual health
questions.explanation: Amos 2:4 mentions that their lies caused them to err after the ways of their fathers, highlighting the importance of faithful family and spiritual upbringing (Amos 2:4).

questions.question: A believer wants to understand the consequences of rejecting God’s Word. What does Amos 2:12 reveal about the dangers of silencing God’s messengers?
options: Commanding prophets not to prophesy leads to spiritual oppression
Silencing God’s word has no serious impact
Only positive messages should be shared
Prophets should be ignored if their message is hard
questions.correctAnswer: Commanding prophets not to prophesy leads to spiritual oppression
questions.explanation: Amos 2:12 condemns the act of forbidding prophets to speak, teaching that rejecting God’s word results in spiritual decline and oppression (Amos 2:12).

questions.question: How does Amos 2:3 encourage believers to trust God’s justice rather than taking matters into their own hands in difficult situations?
options: God will remove judges and princes, showing His sovereign justice
We should rely only on human courts for justice
Taking personal vengeance is justified
God ignores injustices until they escalate
questions.correctAnswer: God will remove judges and princes, showing His sovereign justice
questions.explanation: Amos 2:3 shows God’s authority to cut off judges and princes, reminding believers to trust His justice rather than personal retaliation (Amos 2:3).

questions.question: Based on Amos 2:2, how can believers view God’s discipline during turbulent times in their lives?
options: God’s discipline, like fire consuming palaces, is purposeful and leads to restoration
Discipline is a sign God has abandoned us
All hardship is punishment without hope
God’s discipline is random and unfair
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline, like fire consuming palaces, is purposeful and leads to restoration
questions.explanation: Amos 2:2 describes God sending fire upon Moab’s palaces, illustrating that His discipline is purposeful, aimed at correction and eventual restoration (Amos 2:2, 2:5).

hard.title: Amos Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 2.

questions.question: What specific transgression of Moab is mentioned in Amos 2:1 that led to God's punishment?
options: Burning the bones of the king of Edom into lime
Idolatry and child sacrifice
Oppression of the poor
Breaking the covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Burning the bones of the king of Edom into lime
questions.explanation: Amos 2:1 states that Moab burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime, which is the specific transgression cited for punishment.

questions.question: What is the nature of the punishment that will come upon Moab as described in Amos 2:2?
options: A fire that devours the palaces of Kerioth
A plague of locusts
A flood that destroys the land
Exile to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: A fire that devours the palaces of Kerioth
questions.explanation: Amos 2:2 indicates God will send a fire to consume Moab's palaces in Kerioth, symbolizing destruction.

questions.question: According to Amos 2:4, why will Judah face punishment?
options: Because they despised the law of the LORD and did not keep His commandments
Because they allied with foreign nations
Because they built high places for Baal
Because they refused to pay tithes
questions.correctAnswer: Because they despised the law of the LORD and did not keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Amos 2:4 clearly states Judah's punishment is due to despising God's law and not keeping His commandments.

questions.question: Which metaphor describes the Amorite people in Amos 2:9?
options: Their height was like the height of the cedars and they were strong as the oaks
They were as swift as the gazelle and fierce as lions
They were like the desert wind, unpredictable and destructive
They were as numerous as the stars in the sky
questions.correctAnswer: Their height was like the height of the cedars and they were strong as the oaks
questions.explanation: Amos 2:9 uses the simile comparing the Amorite's height to cedars and their strength to oaks to emphasize their formidable nature.

questions.question: What historical event does Amos 2:10 refer to that involves Israel and the Amorite?
options: The Exodus from Egypt and 40 years in the wilderness to possess the land of the Amorite
The conquest of Canaan under Joshua
The captivity in Babylon
The building of Solomon's temple
questions.correctAnswer: The Exodus from Egypt and 40 years in the wilderness to possess the land of the Amorite
questions.explanation: Amos 2:10 recalls God bringing Israel from Egypt and leading them through the wilderness to take possession of Amorite land, referencing the Exodus narrative.

questions.question: How does Amos 2:11 illustrate God's provision of spiritual leadership to Israel?
options: God raised up sons as prophets and young men as Nazarites
God gave them judges to lead in battle
God sent angels to instruct them
God appointed priests from the tribe of Levi
questions.correctAnswer: God raised up sons as prophets and young men as Nazarites
questions.explanation: Amos 2:11 emphasizes God’s raising of prophets and Nazarites, highlighting spiritual leadership and consecration.

questions.question: What act of rebellion against God’s chosen leaders is described in Amos 2:12?
options: Giving Nazarites wine and commanding prophets not to prophesy
Sacrificing children to pagan gods
Ignoring the Sabbath laws
Building idols in the temple courts
questions.correctAnswer: Giving Nazarites wine and commanding prophets not to prophesy
questions.explanation: Amos 2:12 reveals that Israel corrupted Nazarites by giving them wine and silenced prophets, showing rejection of God's messengers.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Amos 2:1-3 to structure the judgment against Moab?
options: A numerical formula 'For three transgressions, and for four'
Chiasm emphasizing cause and effect
Parallelism contrasting Moab and Edom
Typology foreshadowing future exile
questions.correctAnswer: A numerical formula 'For three transgressions, and for four'
questions.explanation: The phrase 'For three transgressions, and for four' is a numerical device used to emphasize the completeness of Moab’s guilt (Amos 2:1).

questions.question: In Amos 2:6-8, what social injustice is Israel accused of that foreshadows later prophetic condemnations in the Bible?
options: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
Ignoring the poor and widows
Oppressing foreigners and strangers
Persecuting prophets and priests
questions.correctAnswer: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
questions.explanation: Amos 2:6 condemns Israel for economic exploitation, a theme echoed in later prophets like Isaiah and Micah.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 2:13-16, even the strongest and most courageous will be unable to save themselves on the day of judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 2:13-16 describes that neither the swift, mighty, nor courageous will deliver themselves, indicating total helplessness before divine judgment.

questions.question: Which phrase in Amos 2:7 indicates a violation of family and social ethics, contributing to the profaning of God's name?
options: A man and his father will go in unto the same maid
They turn aside the way of the meek
They pant after the dust of the earth on the head of the poor
They lay themselves down upon clothes laid to pledge
questions.correctAnswer: A man and his father will go in unto the same maid
questions.explanation: Amos 2:7 highlights this shocking act as a profanation, breaking social and religious holiness laws.

questions.question: How does the punishment of Judah (Amos 2:5) relate to the broader biblical theme of divine retribution for covenant unfaithfulness?
options: Fire devouring palaces symbolizes God's judgment for abandoning His law
Exile to Babylon is directly foretold here
The destruction of the temple is described in detail
The punishment is limited to economic hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Fire devouring palaces symbolizes God's judgment for abandoning His law
questions.explanation: The fire consuming Jerusalem's palaces (Amos 2:5) acts as a symbol of divine retribution consistent with covenant curses in Deuteronomy.

questions.question: What cultural practice involving pledges is condemned in Amos 2:8?
options: Lying down upon clothes laid to pledge by every altar and drinking wine of the condemned
Offering children as pledges to pagan gods
Using temple vessels as collateral for debts
Taking sacred animals as collateral for loans
questions.correctAnswer: Lying down upon clothes laid to pledge by every altar and drinking wine of the condemned
questions.explanation: Amos 2:8 condemns the practice of exploiting sacred pledges and drinking the wine of those under judgment, showing disrespect for holiness.

questions.question: Which theological theme is strongly present in Amos 2:10-12, connecting Israel’s history with their current rebellion?
options: God’s past deliverance contrasted with Israel’s rejection of His prophets
The promise of a messianic king
The call to rebuild the temple
The establishment of a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: God’s past deliverance contrasted with Israel’s rejection of His prophets
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 recall God’s historical deliverance and provision of prophets, yet Israel’s rejection of these leaders reveals their persistent rebellion.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I am pressed under you, as a cart is pressed that is full of sheaves' in Amos 2:13?
options: It symbolizes the weight of Israel’s sin oppressing God
It describes Israel’s agricultural prosperity
It signifies God’s blessing upon the harvest
It illustrates the strength of Israel’s military
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the weight of Israel’s sin oppressing God
questions.explanation: Amos 2:13 uses this metaphor to depict how Israel’s sins burden God, emphasizing the gravity of their rebellion.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Amos 2:1, what specific sin of Moab provoked God's judgment?
options: They burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime
They oppressed the poor and needy
They worshiped false gods
They committed adultery
questions.correctAnswer: They burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime
questions.explanation: Amos 2:1 explicitly states that Moab's transgression was burning the bones of the king of Edom into lime, a grievous disrespect to the dead. This shows God's justice against profaning sacred things, consistent with Deuteronomy 21:23 and 2 Kings 23:16-20 where respect for the dead is commanded.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare upon Moab for their sins in Amos 2:2?
options: A fire shall devour the palaces of Kerioth
They shall be exiled to Babylon
Their crops shall fail
They shall be swallowed by the sea
questions.correctAnswer: A fire shall devour the palaces of Kerioth
questions.explanation: Amos 2:2 promises fire upon Moab that will consume the palaces of Kerioth, symbolizing God's judgment by destruction of their power and pride, paralleling other prophetic judgments such as in Ezekiel 21:3-4 and Jeremiah 49:13-14.

questions.question: In Amos 2:4, what is the primary reason for God's judgment on Judah?
options: They have despised the law of the LORD and not kept His commandments
They worshiped Baal idols
They oppressed foreigners
They built high places for sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: They have despised the law of the LORD and not kept His commandments
questions.explanation: Amos 2:4 identifies Judah's sin as despising God's law and failing to keep His commandments, leading to error and following their ancestors' sinful ways. This aligns with themes in Jeremiah 2:8 and Hosea 4:6 regarding Israel's covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What imagery does Amos use in Amos 2:6 to describe Israel's injustice?
options: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
Building high towers to reach heaven
Drinking the blood of the innocent
Offering sacrifices to false gods
questions.correctAnswer: Selling the righteous for silver and the poor for a pair of shoes
questions.explanation: Amos 2:6 uses this vivid image to depict the corruption and exploitation in Israel, showing the devaluation of justice and human dignity, which echoes Micah 3:11 and Isaiah 1:23 condemning bribery and oppression.

questions.question: According to Amos 2:7, which of the following was NOT a sin committed by Israel?
options: Men and their fathers going in unto the same maid to profane God's name
Panting after the dust on the heads of the poor
Establishing altars to the true God
Turning aside the way of the meek
questions.correctAnswer: Establishing altars to the true God
questions.explanation: Amos 2:7 condemns sins such as sexual immorality and oppression, but does not accuse Israel of establishing true altars; rather, it criticizes improper worship (Amos 2:8). The true worship of God is commended elsewhere (Deuteronomy 12:4-5).

questions.question: What did God do for Israel as recalled in Amos 2:10?
options: Brought them up from Egypt and led them forty years through the wilderness
Gave them the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai
Built the temple in Jerusalem
Anointed a king for them
questions.correctAnswer: Brought them up from Egypt and led them forty years through the wilderness
questions.explanation: Amos 2:10 recalls God's deliverance of Israel from Egypt and guidance through the wilderness, foundational acts of salvation history also recounted in Exodus 12:51, Deuteronomy 8:2, and Psalm 78:12.

questions.question: In Amos 2:11, what roles did God raise up among Israel's sons and young men?
options: Prophets and Nazarites
Kings and priests
Judges and warriors
Scribes and elders
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets and Nazarites
questions.explanation: Amos 2:11 states God raised up prophets to proclaim His word and Nazarites to live consecrated lives, reflecting God's provision for spiritual leadership, similar to Samuel (1 Samuel 1:11) and John the Baptist (Luke 1:15).

questions.question: What accusation does God make against Israel regarding the prophets and Nazarites in Amos 2:12?
options: They gave the Nazarites wine to drink and commanded the prophets not to prophesy
They honored the prophets above the priests
They built houses for the Nazarites
They listened eagerly to the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They gave the Nazarites wine to drink and commanded the prophets not to prophesy
questions.explanation: Amos 2:12 condemns Israel for corrupting the Nazarites and silencing the prophets, an act of rebellion against God's messengers, paralleling 1 Kings 18:17-18 and Jeremiah 26:16-18 where prophets face opposition.

questions.question: What metaphor does God use to describe His burden under Israel's sins in Amos 2:13?
options: Pressed under a cart full of sheaves
Like a lion stalking its prey
A pot boiling over
A vine withering away
questions.correctAnswer: Pressed under a cart full of sheaves
questions.explanation: Amos 2:13 uses the metaphor of a cart pressed down by sheaves to illustrate the heavy burden of Israel's sins upon God, emphasizing His righteous indignation, consistent with Isaiah 63:9 and Habakkuk 1:13 describing God's dealings with sin.

questions.question: What fate does Amos 2:14 predict for the swift and mighty in the day of the Lord?
options: The flight shall perish and the strong will not strengthen their force
They will conquer their enemies and establish peace
They will be exalted as kings
They will find refuge in the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: The flight shall perish and the strong will not strengthen their force
questions.explanation: Amos 2:14 warns that in the day of judgment, even the swift and strong will fail to save themselves, highlighting God's sovereign power and the ultimate futility of human strength, echoed in Job 9:11 and Zephaniah 1:17.

questions.question: According to Amos 2:15, which of these will NOT deliver himself in the day of judgment?
options: He that handleth the bow
He who builds houses
He who plants vineyards
He who teaches the law
questions.correctAnswer: He that handleth the bow
questions.explanation: Amos 2:15 states that neither the archer, the swift runner, nor the horse rider will save themselves, emphasizing the inevitability of God's judgment. This corresponds with Jeremiah 51:3 and Nahum 1:9 about the futility of relying on human might.

questions.question: What does Amos 2:16 say about the courageous among the mighty on the day of the Lord?
options: He shall flee away naked
He shall stand firm
He shall be honored
He shall be clothed in righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: He shall flee away naked
questions.explanation: Amos 2:16 declares that even the brave and powerful will flee naked in shame, illustrating total defeat and humiliation before God’s judgment, a theme also found in Isaiah 20:4 and Ezekiel 7:18.

questions.question: How does Amos 2:8 describe the corrupt practices related to altars among Israel?
options: They lay themselves down on clothes taken as pledges and drink the wine of the condemned in the house of their god
They offer sacrifices with pure hearts
They fast and pray earnestly
They rebuild the altar according to God’s command
questions.correctAnswer: They lay themselves down on clothes taken as pledges and drink the wine of the condemned in the house of their god
questions.explanation: Amos 2:8 condemns Israel’s exploitation of the poor through pledges and drinking wine in the temple, showing hypocrisy and injustice, paralleling Isaiah 1:11-17 and Micah 6:6-8.

questions.question: What Old Testament historical act of God is recalled in Amos 2:9 to remind Israel of His past deliverance?
options: God destroyed the Amorite whose height was like cedars and strength like oaks
God parted the Red Sea
God gave manna in the wilderness
God made a covenant with Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: God destroyed the Amorite whose height was like cedars and strength like oaks
questions.explanation: Amos 2:9 recalls God’s conquest over the Amorite, a mighty enemy, as a reminder of His sovereign power and faithfulness, consistent with Numbers 21:21-35 and Deuteronomy 2:24-37.

questions.question: What theological theme is strongly emphasized throughout Amos chapter 2 regarding God's nature?
options: God’s justice in punishing covenantal unfaithfulness
God’s indifference to human sin
God’s preference for foreign nations
God’s acceptance of all religious practices
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice in punishing covenantal unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The chapter repeatedly emphasizes that God will not overlook transgressions but will execute justice due to covenantal breaches (Amos 2:1,4,6), which is consistent with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 89:14, and Romans 3:25-26 highlighting God's righteous judgment.
